ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course is essentially just getting course credit for research in a lab. That said, don't underestimate the writing assignments that go along with it (1-page abstract, 5-page midterm report, 15-page final report). They take a good amount of time and can be difficult to meet the page minimums for.

You work with an individual professor on a project over the course of the semester and submit updates to the DUS. It's a great course for teaching you about the research process and is highly self-motivated/self-led.

MENG 471 is an independent research project, carried out under the mentorship of faculty advisors. The course is a requirement for MechE ABET students, but, even if you are not required to take the course, I strongly suggest taking at least a semester to do research. It is a completely independent, self-driven setting through which students can gain a lot.
I got an excellent insight into real engineering problems and problem solving. Something I would recommend every MechE student to do.

Definitly work with a partner and split up the tasks! It's a lot more fun that way and not as intensive. Have a clear idea of what you want to do going in -- there are mentors everywhere, but you can't go to them with nothing and expect help!
I would say that MENG 471 is an awesome opportunity to become involved in a great project and highly recommend it to any mechanical engineering student.
It's pretty chill. There's a 1 page abstract, 5-6 page midterm, 15 page final paper, and a 10 minute presentation. Your experience depends almost completely on your PI.
